title: Make Your Art Move: Spinning Kaleidoscope
description:
Take your artwork to a new level by adding movement. In this at-home workshop you will learn how to use cams (a.k.a. camshafts), levers, the wind and your own muscle power to bring your artwork to life. All techniques used will be mechanical.

In Make Your Art Move: Spinning Kaleidoscope, you'll use different measurement methods to create symmetry in shapes on a piece of cardboard paper. Then you'll apply various construction techniques to allow your kaleidoscope to spin using a hand crank.

You'll have the opportunity to get personal feedback from instructors and other participants, and we'll create a video gallery of everyone's work.

Click here for more information﻿

title: Exploring Careers in Science and Engineering
description:
This is an exciting time to be a scientist or an engineer! How would you like to be in on the action behind new discoveries for medicine or design new structures for urban areas? Would you like to examine the inner world of microscopic organisms, work with animals and the environment, or develop new materials to enrich lives?

Exploring Careers in Science & Engineering gives you the opportunity to talk with scientists and engineers in the field as they describe their research and projects, and how they got there. Practice some of the essential skills needed to be successful. We will also explore career planning and the importance of building a network through volunteering and internships. This program will be offered throughout the year with a focus on a different area of science or engineering.

Click here for more information

title: Find Your Voice: Digital Media Career Exploration
description:
In Find Your Voice, you become an online creator. This session takes you through the process of identifying your creative voice, refining your public identities and creating your own platform. You'll explore blogging, podcasting and video production, hear from industry experts and create your own digital content based on your chosen topic.

Click here for more information

title: Building Terrain in Unity
description:
Are you interested in video games, video game graphics or computer programming? Have you ever wanted to develop your own video game? Learn the basics of how to create your own game, and build terrains your player can move through using professional software by Unity.

Instruction will include a combination of live online interactions with NIU faculty and staff, along with recorded videos and downloadable step-by-step instruction.

title: Minecraft Virtual World Designer
description:
Are you interested in Minecraft, block and JavaScript programming, modifying skins, 3D development or video games? This fun online workshop helps to develop skills in coding, problem solving, graphic design and teamwork. Learn how to build 3D worlds in a community server, while you learn the basics of coding logic. Learn through a combination of live, online interactions with NIU faculty and staff, recorded videos, and downloadable step-by-step instruction.

You'll need a stable internet connection and a computer that meets our computer hardware and software requirements. You'll also need a computer mouse for PC, MAC or Chromebook; headphones with microphone capability; and a webcam.

Students will receive a login for our online webinar tool and the learning management system before the start of each session. We use the Minecraft Education Edition, which is available on Windows, MAC, iPad and Chromebook. Your login will be provided on the first day and will provide access to Minecraft for the duration of the course.

Click here for more information

title: Make Your Art Move: Automata
description:
Take your artwork to a new level by adding movement. In this at-home workshop you will learn how to use cams (a.k.a. camshafts), levers, the wind and your own muscle power to bring your artwork to life. All techniques used will be mechanical.

In Make Your Art Move: Automata, you'll use pieces of cardboard to create a moving sculpture that is powered through a hand crank. The goal is to create pieces that can interlock with one another to allow movement to occur, such as spinning or up and down movements.

You'll have the opportunity to get personal feedback from instructors and other participants, and we'll create a video gallery of everyone's work.

Click here for more information

title: Make Your Art Move: Mobiles
description:
Take your artwork to a new level by adding movement. In this at-home workshop you will learn how to use cams (a.k.a. camshafts), levers, the wind and your own muscle power to bring your artwork to life. All techniques used will be mechanical.

In Make Your Art Move: Mobiles, you'll use different construction techniques to build a hanging sculpture that moves when the wind passes through it. We'll observe how balance is maintained even when the sculpture is moving.

You'll have the opportunity to get personal feedback from instructors and other participants, and we'll create a video gallery of everyone's work.

Click here for more information

title: Make a Space Game in GameMaker
description:
Are you interested in making your own video games but don't know where to start? In this workshop, we'll cover the game development engine GameMaker, making an 8-bitinspired classic space game and developing game narratives.

Instruction will include a combination of live online interactions with NIU faculty and staff, along with recorded videos and downloadable step-by-step instruction.

title: Nature Studies and Expression
description:
Look, listen, smell. Winter has a vibe all its own.

In this winter edition of Nature: Study & Expression, we'll head into our backyards and local parks to discover how nature endures the hardships of the season and seek evidence of those who migrated away until the spring. This workshop will teach you how to observe and record nature in a journal. Let your curiosity guide your thinking as you develop questions that can be used for investigations on anything from animal behavior to ecology.

This program will also introduce participants to a variety of artists and authors who are inspired by nature to create their art. Activities include investigations and creative projects.

Click here for more information

title: Become a Weather Forecaster 3: Precipitation and Storms
description:
Before satellites and advanced radar, weather forecasts were made by understanding cloud formations and wind direction.  As a beginning weather forecaster, you'll explore the science of weather systems and use your senses to make your own weather forecasts. In each session, you'll make your own weather instruments and engage in fun, hands-on activities that will increase your understanding of weather forecasting.

In Become a Weather Forecaster 3, we'll focus the types of precipitation and learn how to identify different storms. You'll use household items to investigate and create models of both tornadoes and blizzards.

Click here for more information

title: Make Your Art Move: Stabiles
description:
Take your artwork to a new level by adding movement. In this at-home workshop you will learn how to use cams (a.k.a. camshafts), levers, the wind and your own muscle power to bring your artwork to life. All techniques used will be mechanical.

In Make Your Art Move: Stabiles, you'll use different construction techniques to build a base and moving parts. The goal is to understand the science of balance as you create artwork that can balance on a fulcrum.

You'll have the opportunity to get personal feedback from instructors and other participants, and we'll create a video gallery of everyone's work.

title: Become a Weather Forecaster 2: Air Pressure, Wind, Clouds and Fog
description:
Before satellites and advanced radar, weather forecasts were made by understanding cloud formations and wind direction.  As a beginning weather forecaster, you'll explore the science of weather systems and use your senses to make your own weather forecasts. In each session, you'll make your own weather instruments and engage in fun, hands-on activities that will increase your understanding of weather forecasting.

In Become a Weather Forecaster 2, you'll investigate air pressure and wind.  You'll also explore the types of clouds and explain what each type means for the upcoming weather.

Click here for more information

title: Astronomy Days
description:
Join the Museum and the Raleigh Astronomy Club to help you see the big picture — of the Universe! From virtual crafts and activities to moon zooms, lectures to LEGOs, space enthusiasts of all ages will find something to do at Astronomy Days.  This year Astronomy Days is VIRTUAL!  Join us for 7 days of astronomical programming! Check out the program schedule and register HERE ! Sign language upon request 72 hours prior to event. Closed captioning for all live programs except videos and movies.

¡Únete al Museo y al Club de Astronomía de Raleigh para observar el Universo… desde otra perspectiva! Desde manualidades y actividades virtuales hasta observar la Luna de cerca, desde charlas sobre el espacio hasta crear con LEGOs, tenemos de todo para entusiastas del espacio de todas las edades durante el Astronomy Days. ¡Este año el Astronomy Days es VIRTUAL! ¡Acompáñanos durante 7 días llenos de programas astronómicamente geniales!

description:

This virtual summit will provide students with an inside look at the career paths of 19 female leaders in the healthcare industry - including CEOs running multi-million dollar companies and founding visionaries in the health tech space. This is a great opportunity for students that are high school juniors and seniors all the way to graduate/medical students.

 It's a great opportunity for internships, scholarships, mentorship, and networking!

Participants must pre-register by emailing Miss Val at vcyouthlib@gmail.com and giving her the ages of the kids participating, along with basic contact info. Any participants wishing to enjoy all of the activities should plan to schedule a pickup of supplies on January 8 or 9﻿ through the library's curbside pickup service. Upon receiving the registration information, Miss Val will send participants the Zoom link and password. The event will start exactly at 4 pm.

title: Aerospace College and Career Exploration and Selection System (ACCESS)
description:
Airway Science is launching ACCESS --﻿ a program designed to reconnect young people with education, training, and support services. Our goal is to assist students in completing their high school studies while helping them explore Aerospace Industry career pathways and post-secondary options. 

﻿Our Explore Aerospace series introduces students to six topics: introduction to flight, powerplants, commercial space, solar system, robotics, and drones. Students will spend 10 hours learning about each topic virtually with Kerbal Space Program, an immersive educational video game encompassing aerospace technology, and onsite in NE Portland where participants can fly simulators, build drones, rebuild an aircraft engine, and more. 

﻿ASK programs provide informal Career & Technical Education (CTE) through our applied engineering curriculum that includes developing skills that are universally applicable across multiple trades, such as learning to read plans, riveting, measuring, fitting, electrical systems, engine systems, etc. Our structure is intended to prepare the whole student for a career, focusing on soft skills that are necessary for most careers regardless of industry. In addition, our locations and business partners integrate into our program the opportunity for on-the-job exposure to all aspects of the Aerospace Industry. Our program introduces students to a wide range of skills and competencies both specific to the industry and generalized for success in any field, equipping them for continued education toward a well-paying, self-sustaining career.
attention: ['Girls', 'Students at risk from dropping out of school']

title: Homeschool Day at the Science Mill- Chemistry
description: Fizz, foam, bubble, bang—mix things up with Careers in Chemistry at January's Homeschool Days! Solve chemistry riddles and explore the science behind chemical reactions that make foaming geysers and floating blobs. Hear about unexpected chemistry careers and the future of the field in a video interview with chemistry professor Amanda Spiewak. All young learners are welcome to join Homeschool Day, including learning pods and those with asynchronous school schedules.

title: Our Planet, Our Purpose: STEM for Changemaking Challenge
description:
The Our Planet, Our Purpose: STEM for Changemaking Challenge is a social innovation challenge for young changemakers (ages 14-20) in the United States who are working to address sustainability issues. 

25 winning projects will each receive $2,000 in seed funding and will be invited to our virtual Changemaker Summit, a three-day immersive experience with mentorship, coaching, and skill building. Applications are due by February 11, 2021. 

Apply by January 14, 2021 for a chance to win an additional $1,000 early entry prize!

title: Winter Wonder lab Party
description:
Are you looking for the perfect touch of winter fun to add to your holiday event? Our Mad Science Winter Wonder Lab Program is just the thing. Have your audience gasping and laughing at the Mad Scientist's exciting and merry science experiments. All will have a wonderful time of giddy goodness and festive fun! Each child will make a winter take home item. Up to 20 kids. $199 and up.

You can make a reservation here.

description:
This festive program will have your kids gasping and laughing at the Mad Scientist's exciting and merry science experiments. The Mad Scientist will introduce the audience to a mysterious North Pole rock that turns out to be Dry Ice. The Mad Scientist will make bubbling potions, popping corks, shivering quarters and clouds of fog. Create slimy sludge or insta-snow to keep! Up to 20 kids. $199

You can register here.

description:
This festive party will have your preschoolers gasping and laughing at the Mad Scientist's exciting and merry science experiments. Experience an amazing "Season of Lights", and make your own flutter flake and 3-D snowflake to keep, along with your special rainbow glasses! Up to 20 kids. $119.

You can register here.

title: Cotton Candy Cane
description:
We bring the Cotton Candy machine to your party and change the state of matter with “good taste”. Yes, science is all around us. 15 minutes Cotton Candy is available to all in attendance as an add-on to parties and workshops, also available as a Discovery Station. Add $30 and 15 minutes per finale. $199 for one hour stations, $179/hour for 2+ hours.

Call us here to request:  (704) 561-9996

title: Leap into Science - Feb 25
description: Our Program today will be a Preschool Workshop from Leap into Science, intended for families with children through ages 3-5. We'll read stories and participate in activities that will explore light and shadows.  Leap into Science is a nationwide program that integrates open-ended science activities with children's books, designed for children ages 3-10.  ﻿   Program will take place on Thursday, February 25 from 10:00-11:00 a.m.

program:
{'title': 'LEAP into Science/Cedar City Library', 'description': '

\ufeffLibrary service in Cedar City is now well over 100 years old. title: Make Art and Storytelling Come Alive with Scratch
description:
Do you enjoy the arts? Do you enjoy writing or storyboarding? Are you interested in creating art? If so, this two-day workshop is for you! Get creative by writing a short story and then animate it using Scratch. You will start by learning to create your own art with basic vector software. Then, you will animate it yourself in Scratch and build into your own digital story. Please pack a peanut free snack, lunch, and drink daily.  

Date(s): Two Saturdays - January 23 and January 30, 2021

Times: 9 am - 3 pm

Grades: 6 – 8

Price: $165 (includes materials for in-person.)

Maximum Size: nine students

Where: Osterville Village Library, 43 Wianno Ave, Osterville, MA  02655 

Note: This is an in-person STEM workshop. The curriculum is developed to offer online via Zoom, if necessary.

Register: https://juniortech.org/make-art-and-storytelling-come-alive-with-scratch/

title: Exploring Ethics: Neuromodulation: Diagnosis and Therapy for Brain and Spinal Cord Disorders
description:
Researchers are exploring the exciting possibility that electrical stimulation of nerve cells of brain and spinal cord could aid in tumor resections, monitor epilepsy, bypass spinal cord injury to cure paralysis, as well as treat other diseases of the nervous system and beyond. Bioelectronic neuromodulation devices are evolving as the gold standard and are projected to impact the lives of millions of people. At UC San Diego, collaborations across engineering and medicine aim to bring the latest technological advances to patient care. This talk will cover the development and clinical translation of UCSD's multi-thousand channel microelectrode arrays to map the human brain and spinal cord. The talk will provide a perspective on global efforts in neuromodulation devices and summarize lessons learned in the technological, medical, and regulatory fronts.

Guest Speaker:   

Shadi Dayeh, PhD, Professor, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of California San Diego, Integrated Electronics and Bio-Interfaces Lab. ﻿

Date & Time: March 3, 2021, 5:30 - 7:00pm      

Registration: https://ethicscentermar2021.eventbrite.com/

Website: https://www.ethicscenter.net/march2021/

program:
{'title': 'The Center for Ethics in Science and Technology: Exploring Ethics', 'description': '

The Center for Ethics in Science and Technology host monthly programs from October -June. The Exploring Ethics programs invite the community to meet local scientists from various organizations around San Diego.\xa0\xa0Scientists\xa0discuss their current research and engage with the audience in a Q&A style forum.\xa0

The mission of the Center for Ethics is\xa0to promote science in the public interest through an informed and engaged community.

Why?\xa0

\ufeffScience can benefit society, but not if those affected are left out of the conversation: It is essential to have informed and engaged citizens.\ufeff Academics and researchers have devoted considerable productive study\xa0to both science and ethics, but the Ethics Center was the first\xa0and likely the leading forum dedicated to inviting the public into\xa0conversations about the ethical challenges of new developments in science and technology.\xa0

\xa0What?\xa0

\ufeffThe Ethics Center provides community forums to promote science that benefits everyone by: \xa0 fostering collaborative, unbiased dialogue between scientists and a diverse community about potential implications of science and technology; promoting evidence-based understanding of science and technology; and\xa0 empowering citizens to communicate their needs and values, and make more informed decisions with their wallets, votes, and lives.\xa0 \xa0\xa0

How?\xa0 \ufeff

\ufeffWorking in partnership with diverse academic, industry, and research institutions and organizations, we strive to provide programs and resources that are: Inclusive Unbiased Evidence-based Collaborative

Date/ Time: Wednesdays, 5-7pm\ufeff

title: 2021 Summer Expeditions
description:
Inspiring Girls*﻿ Expeditions invites 16- and 17-year-olds to apply for FREE summer 2021 wilderness science expeditions! Spend 12 days walking on glaciers, sea kayaking in icy fjords, scrambling on rocks, or paddling down a boreal forest river with like-minded teens and instructors. ﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿

You don't need any prior outdoor experience to apply for our 12-day, tuition-free wilderness science programs. ﻿We offer mountaineering expeditions in Alaska, Washington, Canada, Austria, and﻿ Switzerland; sea kayaking and packrafting ﻿programs in Alaska; and rock climbing programs in Colorado.  

What are we looking for? 

Inspiring Girls Expeditions interweaves﻿ science, art, inquiry, and wilderness travel. We seek engaged, multi-faceted, talented folks who embody the human experience; we believe the diversity of our program makes our expeditions so much stronger and insightful. We are looking for applicants who can each bring a unique contribution to the team. We choose the team as a whole, according to what each member brings. ﻿

When selecting our expedition teams, we look for: 

1. Diversity of backgrounds: a range of racial, ethnic, cultural, economic, gender, sexual orientation, ﻿family, and geographic identities and﻿ backgrounds. 

2. Diversity of interests and life experiences: a balance of interest in science, environment, outdoors, art, philosophy, social issues, politics, and more. If you are passionate about something, tell us about it! 

3. Opportunity: We recognize and support applicants who hold minoritized identities and backgrounds and those who may face more significant barriers to entering science, technology, art, and math (STEAM) and outdoor fields. ﻿ 

We do not necessarily seek applicants who are top athletes, have the best grades, or participate in the most extracurricular activities. We are looking for participants who have a genuine interest in science, art, critical thinking, and the outdoors. ﻿

Visit our website to learn more and apply today! The last day to start your application is January 22, 2021. ﻿ Our website also contains information about our COVID-19 policy. ﻿

*Our history began as an organization seeking to create space for girls and women to grow and thrive in historically male-dominated fields. While we acknowledge our name is imperfect, Inspiring Girls Expeditions welcomes cis girls, trans girls, and any girl-identified youth, as well as non-binary and gender non-conforming youth. ﻿﻿

﻿﻿

We believe all young women deserve opportunities to be curious about the world around them. Inspiring Girls Expeditions empowers women through science, art, and wilderness exploration. Every summer, we select teams of nine high school girls to spend twelve days exploring a remote wilderness environment. Each expedition is led by an all-female instructor team made up of professional scientists, artists, and wilderness guides. We currently operate mountaineering expeditions (Girls on Ice Alaska, Girls on Ice Cascades, Girls on Ice Switzerland, and Girls on Ice Canada); kayaking expeditions (Girls on Water and Girls in Icy Fjords), and a rock climbing expedition (Girls on Rock).\xa0

title: DNA Extraction (Virtual Exploration Lab, Grade 5)
description:
Students learn DNA is the genetic material in living organisms that determines traits. Using processes such as precipitation and spooling, students extract DNA from E. coli cells to understand the differences between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells.   The Exploration Lab experience focuses on making abstract scientific concepts real as students engage in hands-on activities grounded in research done at Brookhaven National Laboratory.   

Session Information:
-Flexible instruction whether students are in the classroom or at home
-Interactive, instructor-led session facilitated with students using materials from school or home (can also be demonstration-based if students do not have access to materials)
-Teachers will receive a detailed Teacher Notes guide upon booking
-Secure link to Zoom Gov videoconferencing platform will be provided
-$240 per class for this 1-hour program (BOCES-aidable)

To learn more or to book your virtual field trip, visit: https://www.bnl.gov/education/programs/exploration-labs.php

description:

title: Build a Better Battery Through Chemistry (Virtual Exploration Lab, Grades 6-8)
description:

Students also learn about the battery research being conducted at Brookhaven Lab.

title: Solar Energy (Virtual Exploration Lab, Grades 6-8)
description:
Students are introduced to research being conducted at Brookhaven Lab's Northeast Solar Energy Research Center (NSERC). Students perform hands-on experiments with suggested materials or they interact virtually to analyze  photovoltaic solar panel materials and panel positioning for optimal performance.  

Session Information:
-Flexible instruction whether students are in the classroom or at home
-Interactive, instructor-led session facilitated with students using materials from school or home (can also be demonstration-based if students do not have access to materials)
-Teachers will receive a detailed Teacher Notes guide upon booking
-Secure link to Zoom Gov videoconferencing platform will be provided
-$240 per class for this 1-hour program (BOCES-aidable)

To learn more or to book your virtual field trip, visit: https://www.bnl.gov/education/programs/exploration-labs.php

title: Column Crushers: An Engineering Challenge (Virtual Exploration Lab, Grades 6-8)
description:
When designing columns, tension and compression are the basic forces involved. These forces are explored through demonstrations of structural buckling and compression testing using everyday materials and an Instron testing instrument. Students are tasked with designing, and testing their own columns using readily accessible materials.

Session Information:
-Flexible instruction whether students are in the classroom or at home
-Interactive, instructor-led session facilitated with students using materials from school or home (can also be demonstration-based if students do not have access to materials)
-Teachers will receive a detailed Teacher Notes guide upon booking
-Secure link to Zoom Gov videoconferencing platform will be provided
-$360 per class for this 90-minute program (BOCES-aidable)

To learn more or to book your virtual field trip, visit:  https://www.bnl.gov/education/programs/exploration-labs.php

title: Detecting the Building Blocks of Matter (Virtual Exploration Lab, Grades 6-8)
description:
Scientists use many different types of detectors to “see” subatomic particles. In this session, students will learn about how some of those particle detectors work and see how a diffusion cloud chamber can help them discover subatomic particles all around us. They will then practice their particle detection skills by competing against each other in a game based on the Rutherford scattering experiment.  

Session Information:
-Flexible instruction whether students are in the classroom or at home
-Interactive, instructor-led session facilitated with students using materials from school or home (can also be demonstration-based if students do not have access to materials)
-Teachers will receive a detailed Teacher Notes guide upon booking
-Secure link to Zoom Gov videoconferencing platform will be provided
-$240 per class for this 1-hour program (BOCES-aidable)

To learn more or to book your virtual field trip, visit: https://www.bnl.gov/education/programs/exploration-labs.php

title: Gene Transfer and Genetic Engineering (Virtual Exploration Lab, Grades 6-8)
description:
Students use lab techniques to genetically modify bacteria to glow under ultraviolet light to verify the successful transfer of genes. Practical applications of gene transformation technology is in the development of human insulin for diabetics and to create plants that are resistant to pests.  

Session Information:
-Flexible instruction whether students are in the classroom or at home
-Interactive, instructor-led session facilitated with students using materials from school or home (can also be demonstration-based if students do not have access to materials)
-Teachers will receive a detailed Teacher Notes guide upon booking
-Secure link to Zoom Gov videoconferencing platform will be provided
-$240 per class for this 1-hour program (BOCES-aidable)

To learn more or to book your virtual field trip, visit: https://www.bnl.gov/education/programs/exploration-labs.php

title: Nanotechnology - Small Things Bring Big Change (Virtual Exploration Lab, Grades 6-8)
description:
Scientists have discovered that materials at the nanoscale, measured in billionths of a meter, behave differently than at the macroscale. In this session, students will learn about the size of a nanometer and how properties can be varied by making changes at the nanoscale.  

Session Information:
-Flexible instruction whether students are in the classroom or at home
-Interactive, instructor-led session facilitated with students using materials from school or home (can also be demonstration-based if students do not have access to materials)
-Teachers will receive a detailed Teacher Notes guide upon booking
-Secure link to Zoom Gov videoconferencing platform will be provided
-$360 per class for this 90-minute program (BOCES-aidable)

To learn more or to book your virtual field trip, visit: https://www.bnl.gov/education/programs/exploration-labs.php

title: Protein Structural Biology in 3D (Virtual Exploration Lab, Grades 6-8)
description:
Students will learn about how scientists study proteins and how the structure of a protein determines its function. They will then access the NCBI protein databank to manipulate protein models and discover various structures for themselves.  

Session Information:
-Flexible instruction whether students are in the classroom or at home
-Interactive, instructor-led session facilitated with students using materials from school or home (can also be demonstration-based if students do not have access to materials)
-Teachers will receive a detailed Teacher Notes guide upon booking
-Secure link to Zoom Gov videoconferencing platform will be provided
-$240 per class for this 1-hour program (BOCES-aidable)

To learn more or to book your virtual field trip, visit: https://www.bnl.gov/education/programs/exploration-labs.php

title: Spectroscopy (Virtual Exploration Lab, Grades 6-8)
description:
Brookhaven National Lab's National Synchrotron Light Source II (NSLS II) uses powerful X-rays to determine the atomic composition of batteries, proteins, and much more. In this lesson, students will learn the basics of spectroscopy and then apply their skills in an online game of “Name That Element!” May the best spectroscopist win!  

Session Information:
-Flexible instruction whether students are in the classroom or at home
-Interactive, instructor-led session facilitated with students using materials from school or home (can also be demonstration-based if students do not have access to materials)
-Teachers will receive a detailed Teacher Notes guide upon booking
-Secure link to Zoom Gov videoconferencing platform will be provided
-$240 per class for this 1-hour program (BOCES-aidable)

To learn more or to book your virtual field trip, visit: https://www.bnl.gov/education/programs/exploration-labs.php

title: Accelerator Science (Virtual Exploration Lab, Grades 9-12)
description:
Brookhaven National Lab's Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) uses electric and magnetic fields to accelerate charged particles in a circle to understand the fundamental building blocks of matter. In this session, students will virtually use our table-top particle accelerators with the help of BNL staff, and then they will graph their data to find the line of best fit and calculate the charge to mass ratio of the electron.

Session Information:
-Flexible instruction whether students are in the classroom or at home
-Interactive, instructor-led session facilitated with students using materials from school or home (can also be demonstration-based if students do not have access to materials)
-Teachers will receive a detailed Teacher Notes guide upon booking
-Secure link to Zoom Gov videoconferencing platform will be provided
-$360 per class for this 90-minute program (BOCES-aidable)

To learn more or to book your virtual field trip, visit: https://www.bnl.gov/education/programs/exploration-labs.php

title: Bioinformatics (Virtual Exploration Lab, Grades 9-12)
description:
Brookhaven National Lab's Computational Science Initiative (CSI) is working to develop new methods and tools to extract knowledge from Big Data. In this session, students will work with C++ code and statistics to study genetic code from various organisms, including the virus that causes COVID-19. No coding knowledge is needed to enjoy this experience!  

Session Information:
-Flexible instruction whether students are in the classroom or at home
-Interactive, instructor-led session facilitated with students using materials from school or home (can also be demonstration-based if students do not have access to materials)
-Teachers will receive a detailed Teacher Notes guide upon booking
-Secure link to Zoom Gov videoconferencing platform will be provided
-$360 per class for this 90-minute program (BOCES-aidable)

To learn more or to book your virtual field trip, visit: https://www.bnl.gov/education/programs/exploration-labs.php

title: Citric Acid Process of Soil Remediation (Virtual Exploration Lab, Grades 9-12)
description:
Citric acid, a naturally occurring organic complexing agent, can be used to remove toxic metals from soil. Students learn about the technique that Brookhaven Lab developed by performing a simple procedure to remove and recover iron, a model for a metal contaminant, by forming a soluble iron-citrate complex. Next, students will use a spectrophotometer to analyze the concentration of iron in the soil.

Session Information:
-Flexible instruction whether students are in the classroom or at home
-Interactive, instructor-led session facilitated with students using materials from school or home (can also be demonstration-based if students do not have access to materials)
-Teachers will receive a detailed Teacher Notes guide upon booking
-Secure link to Zoom Gov videoconferencing platform will be provided
-$360 per class for this 90-minute program (BOCES-aidable)

To learn more or to book your virtual field trip, visit: https://www.bnl.gov/education/programs/exploration-labs.php

title: (AP Lab) DNA Analysis - Cutting DNA with Enzymes (Virtual Exploration Lab, Grades 9-12)
description:
Using the tools of recombinant DNA, called restriction enzymes, students utilize the same tools used in biotechnology to analyze DNA and determine the identity of an unknown endonuclease.

Session Information:
-Flexible instruction whether students are in the classroom or at home
-Interactive, instructor-led session facilitated with students using materials from school or home (can also be demonstration-based if students do not have access to materials)
-Teachers will receive a detailed Teacher Notes guide upon booking
-Secure link to Zoom Gov videoconferencing platform will be provided
-$480 per class for this 2-hour program (BOCES-aidable)

To learn more or to book your virtual field trip, visit: https://www.bnl.gov/education/programs/exploration-labs.php

title: Encryption Cyber Security (Virtual Exploration Lab, Grades 9-12)
description:
Brookhaven National Lab takes all safety very seriously, and that includes cyber security! In this lesson, students will learn about simple encryption and decryption of text files using a short C++ program. They will first try to decrypt a message by hand and then compare that with decrypting it using the code. Then using their new skills they will move on to decrypt a more challenging message. No coding knowledge is needed to enjoy this experience!

Session Information:
-Flexible instruction whether students are in the classroom or at home
-Interactive, instructor-led session facilitated with students using materials from school or home (can also be demonstration-based if students do not have access to materials)
-Teachers will receive a detailed Teacher Notes guide upon booking
-Secure link to Zoom Gov videoconferencing platform will be provided
-$240 per class for this 1-hour program (BOCES-aidable)

To learn more or to book your virtual field trip, visit: https://www.bnl.gov/education/programs/exploration-labs.php

title: (AP Lab) Gene Transfer and Genetic Engineering (Virtual Exploration Lab, Grades 9-12)
description:
Students will transfer green fluorescent protein and antibiotic resistant genes into E. coli by using genetically engineered plasmid DNA as a vector to carry the genes. The transformed E.coli is expected to grow in a media that contains antibiotic and glow green in the presence of ultraviolet light.

Session Information:
-Flexible instruction whether students are in the classroom or at home
-Interactive, instructor-led session facilitated with students using materials from school or home (can also be demonstration-based if students do not have access to materials)
-Teachers will receive a detailed Teacher Notes guide upon booking
-Secure link to Zoom Gov videoconferencing platform will be provided
-$480 per class for this 2-hour program (BOCES-aidable)

To learn more or to book your virtual field trip, visit: https://www.bnl.gov/education/programs/exploration-labs.php

title: Spectroscopy (Virtual Exploration Lab, Grades 9-12)
description:
Brookhaven National Lab's National Synchrotron Light Source II (NSLS II) uses powerful X-rays to determine the atomic composition of batteries, proteins, and much more. In this lesson, students will learn the basics of spectroscopy and then apply their skills in an online game of “Name That Element!” May the best spectroscopist win!

Session Information:
-Flexible instruction whether students are in the classroom or at home
-Interactive, instructor-led session facilitated with students using materials from school or home (can also be demonstration-based if students do not have access to materials)
-Teachers will receive a detailed Teacher Notes guide upon booking
-Secure link to Zoom Gov videoconferencing platform will be provided
-$240 per class for this 1-hour program (BOCES-aidable)

title: Virus Infection Lab (Virtual Exploration Lab, Grades 9-12)
description:
The study of viruses has impacted our understanding of genetics and biotechnology. Brookhaven National Laboratory developed the T7 expression system, a viral replication “machine” that controls protein production in bacterial cells. Students use the T7 virus as a model to learn how to dilute a virus culture and determine its infectivity on a bacteria host.

Session Information:
-Flexible instruction whether students are in the classroom or at home
-Interactive, instructor-led session facilitated with students using materials from school or home (can also be demonstration-based if students do not have access to materials)
-Teachers will receive a detailed Teacher Notes guide upon booking
-Secure link to Zoom Gov videoconferencing platform will be provided
-$360 per class for this 90-minute program (BOCES-aidable)

To learn more or to book your virtual field trip, visit: https://www.bnl.gov/education/programs/exploration-labs.php

title: Waves and Resonance (Virtual Exploration Lab, Grades 9-12)
description:
Brookhaven National Lab's many particle accelerators use a technology called radiofrequency (RF) cavities to speed up charged particles. This device actually has a lot in common with musical instruments, which use resonance to create sounds. In this session, students will complete an online activity about waves in order to learn about what musical instruments and particle accelerators have in common. Resonance is the key to both!

Session Information:
-Flexible instruction whether students are in the classroom or at home
-Interactive, instructor-led session facilitated with students using materials from school or home (can also be demonstration-based if students do not have access to materials)
-Teachers will receive a detailed Teacher Notes guide upon booking
-Secure link to Zoom Gov videoconferencing platform will be provided
-$240 per class for this 1-hour program (BOCES-aidable)

To learn more or to book your virtual field trip, visit: https://www.bnl.gov/education/programs/exploration-labs.php

WebbVR can be downloaded for free from STEAM or Viveport.

title: TRAPPIST-1 System Scale Model
description: In February 22, 2017, NASA announced the discovery of the largest batch of Earth-sized, habitable-zone planets around a single star –-  TRAPPIST-1A. This activity can be used to create a scale model of the TRAPPIST-1 system in a small space. The model can serve as a hands-on activity or as a pop-up exhibit to share the news with learners. The activity guide is also available in Spanish.﻿﻿

program:
{'title': "NASA's Universe of Learning", 'description': '

NASA\'s Universe of Learning provides resources and experiences that enable diverse audiences to explore fundamental questions in astronomy, experience how science is done, and discover the universe for themselves. Using its direct connection to science and science experts, NASA\'s Universe of Learning creates and delivers timely and authentic resources and experiences for youth, families, and lifelong learners. The goal is to strengthen science learning and literacy, and to enable learners to discover the universe for themselves in innovative, interactive ways that meet today\'s 21st century needs. \ufeffThe program includes astronomical data tools, multimedia resources, exhibits and community programs, and professional learning experiences for informal educators. It is developed through a unique partnership between the Space Telescope Science Institute, Caltech/IPAC, the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, and the Center for Astrophysics | Harvard Smithsonian.

NASA\'s Universe of Learning materials are based upon work supported by NASA under award number NNX16AC65A.\ufeff\xa0 Any opinions, findings, and conclusions \xa0or recommendations expressed in this material are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

program:
{'title': "NASA's Universe of Learning", 'description': '

NASA\'s Universe of Learning provides resources and experiences that enable diverse audiences to explore fundamental questions in astronomy, experience how science is done, and discover the universe for themselves. Using its direct connection to science and science experts, NASA\'s Universe of Learning creates and delivers timely and authentic resources and experiences for youth, families, and lifelong learners. The goal is to strengthen science learning and literacy, and to enable learners to discover the universe for themselves in innovative, interactive ways that meet today\'s 21st century needs. \ufeffThe program includes astronomical data tools, multimedia resources, exhibits and community programs, and professional learning experiences for informal educators. It is developed through a unique partnership between the Space Telescope Science Institute, Caltech/IPAC, the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, and the Center for Astrophysics | Harvard Smithsonian.

NASA\'s Universe of Learning materials are based upon work supported by NASA under award number NNX16AC65A.\ufeff\xa0 Any opinions, findings, and conclusions \xa0or recommendations expressed in this material are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Virtual STEM Club
description:
This virtual STEM Club engages students through six unique STEM Club sessions, each with two live instructors present. Sessions run Feb. 1–April 23 and are offered multiple times throughout a two-week period to accommodate the diverse schedules of each student. One week prior to each session, you will select the class time/date that works best for you. We also provide a recording of each session, in case your child cannot attend a session live.

WHEN: Class schedules will be announced bi-weekly but in general will be offered 3–4:30 p.m. EST or 4–5:30 p.m. EST Monday–Thursday

WHERE?   Zoom virtual classroom  

COST?   $142 (includes all 6 sessions + cost of mailing STEM Club materials to your home)

Session  1: Oceans-  Deepen your understanding of ocean pollution through experiments with CO2 and investigations into ocean clean-up devices.

Session 2: Light & Color-  Explore light, color, and diffraction by building your own spectroscope.

Session  3: The Magic of Light-  Design and build a kaleidoscope while investigating how light can play tricks on our minds, distort images, and create beautiful designs.

Session 4: Air Pressure -Experiment with balloons and bottles to explore the principles of air pressure.

Session  5: Diffusion & Osmosis-  Discover the phenomena of diffusion and osmosis through “growing a rainbow” and experimentation with dialysis tubing.

Session 6: Plants-  Design and build your own plant seed prototype while learning about seed dispersal in plants. 

Register here:  https://tinyurl.com/y4v9q6rh (Registration deadline: January 15, 2021)

For more information, please visit us at: https://www.clemson.edu/centers-institutes/culsoc/virtual-stem-club.html

QUESTIONS?   Please contact us at  culsoc@clemson.edu , 864-656-9939
author: reneel
excerpt: This virtual STEM Club engages students through six unique STEM Club  sessions, each with two live instructors present. Sessions run Feb.  1–April ...
program:
{'title': 'Clemson University Science Outreach Center', 'description': '

The mission of the Clemson University Science Outreach Center \xa0is to inspire and empower the scientist within each of us.

\ufeffTo this end, \xa0we: Make science relevant and fun through hands-on labs, camps and activities for learners of all ages. Engage the public through lectures and discussions of scientific issues. Support classroom teachers through course offerings and lesson ideas.

\ufeffOur programs include: Interactive lab experiences in modern genetics and biotechnology for school and community groups. Summer science and holiday camps. Graduate courses for teachers. TIGERTalks, a monthly science forum. NEW THIS FALL - Virtual Stem Club !

\ufeffThe Clemson University Science Outreach Center is sponsored by Clemson University.

title: Code with immersive 3D games and endless hours of play
description:
Play, it's in our code.

Terminal Two teaches fundamental coding concepts through immersive and engaging games. Built by educators and gamers, we understand what engages kids and how to teach coding concepts in a fun environment instead of a series of stale lessons. Desktop game bundles available now for PC and Mac.

Click here to learn more!﻿
attention: ['Boys', 'Girls', 'Students with disabilities', 'Gifted and talented students', 'Students at risk from dropping out of school']
author: TerminalTwo
excerpt: Play, it's in our code.Terminal Two teaches fundamental coding concepts through immersive and engaging games. Built by educators and gamers, we under...
program:
{'title': 'Terminal Two by Endless Educator Program', 'description': "

Your students love games. \xa0

\xa0You want them to learn.\xa0

\xa0Terminal Two provides high-quality games that equip your kids to learn valuable coding concepts.

You want Educational results Coding is a 21st-century skill and we know it. Robust educational outcomes, collaboration, teamwork, and logic are some of the benefits of teaching coding skills. You need your kids to have these skills in a computer-driven society and we are here to help. Tests are boring Challenges are fun We don't believe that there is any reason why learning code should be discouraging. Making kids memorize code vocabulary or complete pointless coding tasks is the fastest way to get kids to quit coding before they start. Terminal Two games are engaging and immersive, with coding challenges built directly into the stories and gameplay. It has to be as much fun as the games kids love Kids love to create, and code is one of the most empowering creation tools ever. It equips kids with the ability to create anything from a simple code clock to an entire 3D landscape.\xa0

Terminal Two's games are meant to be hacked, so that your child gains valuable computer science skills while seeing their code change the games themselves.\xa0


\xa0Where do I get started?\xa0

\xa0Check out our educator's guide!

\xa0The collection of games in Terminal Two can be played independently or progressively to gain exposure to increasingly advanced coding and programming skills. As players advance from game to game, the programming mechanics in the games also evolve.

description:
This video﻿, created for a STEM Achievement in Baltimore Elementary Schools (SABES) workshop, provides a discussion of the motions of Earth, the Sun, the Moon, and the stars, both as perceived from Earth and as viewed from a solar system perspective. Join Dr. Frank Summers as he covers daily motions, monthly motions and yearly motions, and how they affect our view of the night sky.

title: The True Shape of Orion
description: Constellations are drawn as stick figures connecting bright stars in the  sky. This two-dimensional representation gives the impression that the stars are all at the same distance. In addition, the idea of a "bright star" can be misleading, as the apparent brightness we see depends upon both the star's intrinsic brightness and its distance from Earth. This scientific visualization addresses both of these issues by viewing the Orion constellation from a three-dimensional perspective. The true space  distribution of the constellation as well as how stellar brightness changes with viewing position is revealed by circling around the stars.

title: Colliding Galaxies Video Series
description:
View a tug-of-war between the expansion of the universe and the pull of gravity, where galaxies are caught in the middle. Gravity can cause some galaxies to collide, leaving them scarred and tattered. Others inflict glancing blows that form long tails of debris. Some even merge, radically altering the appearance of the original galaxies. This video series highlights colliding galaxies in relation to the predicted merger between our own Milky Way galaxy and the neighboring Andromeda galaxy.

﻿Galaxy Collisions: Simulation vs. Observations 

Crash of the Titans: Milky Way and Andromeda Collision 

Nighttime Sky View of Future Galaxy Merger 

What Happens When Galaxies Collide?

title: Hubble: Galaxies Across Space and Time
description: This award-winning short film transforms images and data from NASA's Hubble Space Telescope into a voyage that sweeps viewers across the universe and back into cosmic history. The film opens with looming images of two mature galaxies that are relatively nearby Earth, and then pans through the vibrant and diverse panorama of thousands of galaxies in an image from the Great Observatories Origins Deep Survey. The ensuing 3-D journey through these  galaxies provides more than just a new perspective in space; it also takes viewers back in time.

title: Cosmic Concepts: Advantages of Space Telescopes
description: This video is part of the "Cosmic Concepts" video series. It illustrates how space telescopes offer advantages to studying the universe. For example, they are above the blurring effects of Earth's atmosphere, which affords a clearer view of the cosmos. The other major advantage of telescopes being located in space is that all wavelengths of light can be observed. An overview of NASA's Great Observatories is provided, as well.

title: Cosmic Concepts: Infrared Light
description: This video is part of the "Cosmic Concepts" video series. It illustrates how infrared light is heat radiation and how infrared observations have numerous applications wherever temperature is important, such as in medicine, energy audits, and firefighting. An overview of how infrared observations are used in astronomy is provided, as well. Whether one is studying planets, stars, nebulae, galaxies, or the distant universe, infrared astronomy plays an important role.

title: Cosmic Concepts: Electromagnetic Spectrum
description: This video is part of the "Cosmic Concepts" video series. It provides an overview of the electromagnetic spectrum and highlights both visible and invisible wavelengths of light. Explanations of non-visible wavelengths of light and how they relate to everyday life are provided.  A brief overview of how the full electromagnetic spectrum is used by astronomers to study the cosmos is provided, as well.

title: Perspectives on Spiral Galaxies: NGC 4302 and NGC 4298
description: Spiral galaxies are pancake-shaped collections of billions of stars, along with vast clouds of gas and dust. This video illustrates how their  observed shapes can differ greatly depending upon the angle at which they are observed.

title: Horsehead Nebula: Visible Zoom to Infrared Fly-in
description: This video begins with a visible-light zoom into the Horsehead Nebula and a cross-fade to an infrared-light view. The sequence starts with a wide-field, ground-based view of the Orion constellation. The view zooms into the Horsehead region on the left side of Orion's belt. A cross-fade to infrared light reveals a view from NASA's Hubble Space Telescope.  The three-dimensional interpretation has been sculpted to create a wispy and mountainous environment. This imaginative traverse of the glowing, gaseous landscape provides an inspiring spaceflight experience that brings the celestial scene to life.

title: How Do Space Telescopes Break Down Light?
description: The James Webb Space Telescope will use an innovative instrument called an integral field unit (IFU) to capture images and spectra at the same time. This video gives a basic overview of how the IFU works, and explains how telescopes break light down into its component wavelengths or colors.

title: Are All Galaxies the Same?
description: All galaxies are not the same. Some are elliptically shaped; others pinwheel shaped. Many change over time, including our Milky Way, which is gobbling up nearby dwarf galaxies. Learn more in this video.

title: Flight Through the Orion Nebula in Visible and Infrared Light [Ultra HD]
description: This visualization explores the Orion Nebula using both visible and infrared light. The sequence begins with a wide-field view of the sky showing the plane of our Milky Way Galaxy, then zooms down to the scale of the Orion Nebula. The visible light observation (from the Hubble Space Telescope) and the infrared light observation (from the Spitzer Space Telescope) are compared first in two-dimensional images, and then in three-dimensional models. The infrared observations generally show cooler temperature gas and many faint stars ﻿that shine primarily at longer wavelengths. The  visible observations show finer details including the wispy bow shocks and tadpole-shaped proplyds.

title: Deep Field: The Impossible Magnitude of the Universe
description: The Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI) collaborated with Grammy Award-winning composer Eric Whitacre to create this video experience inspired by the Hubble Space Telescope's Deep Field image. Set to a performance of the symphony by the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra, NASA images and visualizations transport the audience from the night sky to the edge of the observable universe. The work also features an 8000-member virtual choir of singers aged 4 through 87 from 120 countries around the globe.

title: The Hubble Space Telescope: Three Decades of Discovery
description: This video montage of more than 600 images from the Hubble Space Telescope celebrates the telescope's 30 years of exploring the cosmos. The rapid sequence of images echoes Hubble's fast pace of exploration. Though numerous, these images are just a glimpse of the data collected by Hubble over the years, and only a tiny sliver of our vast universe.

title: Hubble Ultra Deep Field 3-D Fly-Thru
description: This video features a flight through the Hubble Ultra Deep Field, the most distant visible-light view of the universe. The redshifts of 5,333 galaxies were  converted to distances to assemble a 3-D model of the data. This scientific visualization flies through the data to showcase its true 3-D nature.

title: What Is a Galaxy?
description: Galaxies are concentrations of stars, gas, dust, and dark matter. They come in a variety of shapes and sizes. Some are fated to collide, like the Milky Way and Andromeda. Learn more in this video.

title: Recoloring the Universe
description: Color, Astronomy,﻿ and Coding! Use data from NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory and other satellites on exploded stars, star-forming regions, and black holes to learn basic coding with Recoloring the Universe. By following video tutorials, you will see just how integral coding is in the pursuit of learning about our universe. It's an example of the exciting ways that computer science ﻿is both part of routine tasks in our every﻿day lives and part of the exciting quest to explore the cosmos.
author: hryer
excerpt: Color, Astronomy,﻿ and Coding! Use data from NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory and other  satellites on exploded stars, star-forming regions, and bl...
program:
{'title': "NASA's Universe of Learning", 'description': '

NASA\'s Universe of Learning provides resources and experiences that enable diverse audiences to explore fundamental questions in astronomy, experience how science is done, and discover the universe for themselves. Using its direct connection to science and science experts, NASA\'s Universe of Learning creates and delivers timely and authentic resources and experiences for youth, families, and lifelong learners. The goal is to strengthen science learning and literacy, and to enable learners to discover the universe for themselves in innovative, interactive ways that meet today\'s 21st century needs. \ufeffThe program includes astronomical data tools, multimedia resources, exhibits and community programs, and professional learning experiences for informal educators. It is developed through a unique partnership between the Space Telescope Science Institute, Caltech/IPAC, the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, and the Center for Astrophysics | Harvard Smithsonian.

NASA\'s Universe of Learning materials are based upon work supported by NASA under award number NNX16AC65A.\ufeff\xa0 Any opinions, findings, and conclusions \xa0or recommendations expressed in this material are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Science Briefings
description: NASA's Universe of Learning Science Briefings are professional learning telecons for the informal science education community, done in partnership with the NASA Museum Alliance. These thematic briefings highlight current NASA astrophysics explorations and discoveries from across the suite of NASA astrophysics missions. NASA scientists and engineers provide contemporary science results, and are able to respond to listener questions during the telecon. NASA-developed education and outreach resources, matched to the monthly theme, are included with every briefing. To access an archive of past briefings, go here: https://www.universe-of-learning.org/science-briefings/. ﻿

title: ViewSpace: Interactives & Videos
description:
Explore the hidden universe through the ViewSpace: ﻿﻿Unveiling the Invisible Universe ﻿interactive sliders. Explore astronomical concepts and manipulate the sliders to view objects as they appear across the different parts of the electromagnetic spectrum. Watch ViewSpace videos that feature the latest imagery from satellites and space telescopes, and provide insight into our understanding of the universe. ﻿
﻿

title: MicroObservatory Robotic Telescope Network
description: Explore the universe with telescopes you control over the internet! This web portal provides access to four authentic observing/data experiences - Observing with NASA, Laboratory for the Study of Exoplanets, DIY Planet Search, and the MicroObservatory legacy page.  Users can take their very own space images, join the search for life outside of the solar system, and become part of a community of planet searchers.

title: Flight Through the Orion Nebula in Visible and Infrared Light
description: This visualization explores the Orion Nebula using both visible and infrared light. The sequence begins with a wide-field view of the sky showing the plane of our Milky Way Galaxy, then zooms down to the scale of the Orion Nebula. The visible light observation (from the Hubble Space Telescope) and the infrared light observation (from the Spitzer Space Telescope) are compared first in two-dimensional images, and then in three-dimensional models.

title: Women in Science (Online Series, AR Experience &  Posters)
description: The history of women's contributions to the fields of science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) is long and varied. But it has also often been overlooked or underrepresented. The Women in Science﻿ series highlights only a very few of the women who have made important discoveries and have had a crucial impact on STEM fields. Scroll down to the "For Educators" section to locate the downloadable poster files.

title: Eyes on Exoplanets
description: Get set for launch. Eyes on Exoplanets will fly you to any planet you wish—as long as it's far beyond our solar system. This fully rendered 3D universe is scientifically accurate, allowing you to zoom in  for a close look at more than 1,000 exotic planets known to orbit distant stars. With the click of a mouse, you can visit newly discovered gas giants, ﻿“super Earths," and rocky worlds.﻿

title: 3D Printing the X-Ray Universe
description: Despite our limited abilities to travel to distant objects in outer space, astronomers, computer scientists, and others are developing techniques that nudge astronomy visualization forward from two-dimensional images to images that include time, and also, the third dimension in space. 3D modeling objects in our universe offers a unique tool to understand scientific data. Explore the 3D Printing the X-ray Universe activities to hold a dead star in your hand, print a 3D nova, or learn about SN1987A.

title: Universe Unplugged
description: The Universe Unplugged video series presents exciting astronomical science in playful ways designed to appeal to a broad audience of lifelong learners of all ages, with a special focus on underserved communities in science. Produced at Caltech/IPAC  in Pasadena, California, the videos integrate the talents of celebrities, astronomers, and educators, to communicate the wonders of the universe as revealed by NASA's many astrophysics missions.

title: A Universe of Making and Doing: Paper Circuit Activities
description: Paper circuits function as simple low-voltage electronic circuits made using paper, LED lights, a type of conductive tape such as copper, as well as a small battery for the power source. They can help learners of all ages explore the basics of electricity and conductivity.  These hands-on activities use printable templates for creating simple paper circuits while exploring the science of stars. Good for MakerFaires, libraries, classrooms and other STEM-related events where participants can create their own take-away.

title: Crab Nebula: The Multiwavelength Structure of a Pulsar Wind
description: This visualization features a three-dimensional multiwavelength representation of the Crab Nebula, a pulsar wind nebula that is the remains of an exploded star. It is based on images from NASA's three Great Observatories: the Chandra X-ray Observatory and the Hubble and Spitzer Space Telescopes.

title: NASA's Universe of Learning at Home
description: Being at home doesn't mean you can't explore the universe! NASA's Universe of Learning has activities for learners of all ages to engage in the science of NASA astrophysics from home. Explore everything from our solar system to far away exoplanets, stars and nebula, and the most distant galaxies. Filter resources by audience, science or type!

{'title': "NASA's Universe of Learning", 'description': '

NASA\'s Universe of Learning provides resources and experiences that enable diverse audiences to explore fundamental questions in astronomy, experience how science is done, and discover the universe for themselves. Using its direct connection to science and science experts, NASA\'s Universe of Learning creates and delivers timely and authentic resources and experiences for youth, families, and lifelong learners. The goal is to strengthen science learning and literacy, and to enable learners to discover the universe for themselves in innovative, interactive ways that meet today\'s 21st century needs. \ufeffThe program includes astronomical data tools, multimedia resources, exhibits and community programs, and professional learning experiences for informal educators. title: Shedding New Light on the Whirlpool Galaxy
description: The Whirlpool Galaxy is a magnificent spiral galaxy that has been studied across the spectrum by NASA's Great Observatories. This remarkable video uses two-﻿dimensional images and three-﻿dimensional visualizations to contrast and compare the different views of infrared (Spitzer Space Telescope), visible (Hubble Space Telescope), and X-ray (Chandra X-ray Observatory) observations.

title: 2020-2021 Ohio Invention Convention NO-COST VIRTUAL STEAM/INVENTION/INNOVATION/ENTREPRENEURSHIP program
description:
WHY THE INVENTION CONVENTION IS RIGHT FOR EVERYONE:       

The Invention Convention meets all NGSS , Common Core , and socio-emotional standards. We help your students work toward acquiring their 21 st -Century job skills necessary for jobs that may not have even been created yet.  Problem-solving, curiosity, creativity, critical thinking, determination, entrepreneurship … that is our program. As always, the Invention League team is here to help you with your inventors. The Invention League team understands the stress you are under this year, and the Invention Convention program can be used in any classroom to meet the standards that you need to meet.  You need an ART project? The Invention Convention includes the design process.  You need a SCIENCE project? The Invention Convention meets the Next Generation Science Standards.  You need to do a project in SOCIAL STUDIES ? The Invention Convention meets the College, Career & Civic Life (C3) standards.  MATH ? Yep, our virtual program can be used in your geometry curriculum.  STEAM classes? No question about it.

Links to register: TEACHER REGISTRATION LINK FOR 2020-2021 VIRTUAL PROGRAM YEAR: https://oh.zfairs.com/?f=262740bf-9850-487a-b0fc-93908b4655a8&PersonType=y&FairRType=Teacher 

 INDEPENDENT INVENTOR PROGRAM REGISTRATION LINK FOR THE 2020-2021 VIRTUAL PROGRAM YEAR: https://oh.zfairs.com?f=f2b3b421-2b76-4d23-934a-f85ae98b64bb&stdReg=y&StudentRegPass=6591c94c-08af-4266-baf2-895444c7a9b6

This year we are making things easier than ever for our educators and program leaders to do the Invention Convention program. Our new virtual curriculum is a collaboration between several affiliate states that have gotten together to help you make this VIRTUAL Invention Convention 2020-2021 program year possible. Our Connecticut affiliate collaborator is hosting a mentoring program that allows your students to work directly with Invention Convention alumni inventors virtually together with inventors across the country. They will go through the entire invention process from problem to prototype. This will include helpful suggestions and support on their display board, journal and prototype. Your students are invited to participate in this virtual program.  Our California affiliate collaborator has prepared lesson plans to help implement the IC program remote/virtually, along with Ohio's new/revised 2020-2021 materials.

NEED THE INVENTION LEAGUE TO TAKE OVER FOR YOU THIS YEAR?  If you just cannot make it happen this year in your school or classroom, send your students directly to the Invention League team. We will work with them from registration in our Independent Inventor Program through to their virtual Regional Invention Convention Competition.  The program is free to all students in the state of Ohio, and award-earning students at the Regional and State level will receive CollegeAdvantage 529 savings awards.
attention: ['Students at risk from dropping out of school', 'Gifted and talented students', 'Students with disabilities', 'Girls', 'Boys']

title: Online STEM Class - Web Development
description:
Register your child today at: https://www.dreamsforschools.org/webdev/

In this course, students learn the basics of  HTML & CSS  and be on their way to creating their own website (sometimes the very 1st website for some students). Every week, instructors will be teaching and making available new web development concepts, lecture videos, along with assignments for self-practice.  Students also get project guidelines to start building out their custom website as they go through different assignments & become more confident in their web development skills. 

Key Takeaways: 1) Learn how to program using HTML, CSS, and Bootstrap 2) Create your own portfolio website 3) Learn best practices when creating a website 4) Think creatively, reason with logic, and learn collaboration skills 


﻿Instructor to Student Ratio: 1 to 7

Multiple Classes available from Jan 18 to Mar 26

Classes take place 2x a week on a Monday/Wednesday or Tuesday/Thursday schedule

Class times: 3 - 4 PM, 4 - 5 PM, 5 - 6 PM (PST)

title: Online STEM Class - Coding Games with Scratch
description:
For more information & to register your child, please visit: https://www.dreamsforschools.org/coding-games-with-scratch/

Learn how to develop your own game using Scratch, the drag-and-drop learning platform created by MIT Media Lab.  Use code blocks to bring your creativity to life through games, animations, or even stories. Gain experience in collaborating with friends in every step from design to development to debugging.  ﻿

﻿*Requires access to a computer, internet, and webcam.  

Instructor to Student Ratio: 1 to 7 ﻿ 

Multiple Classes available from Jan 18 to Mar 26 

Classes take place 2x a week on a Monday/Wednesday or Tuesday/Thursday schedule 

Class times: 3 - 4 PM, 4 - 5 PM, 5 - 6 PM (PST)

title: Online STEM Class - Engineering for Kids
description:
For more information & to register your child, please visit: https://www.dreamsforschools.org/engineering-for-kids/

Students in Grades 3 to 5th get hands-on experience with engineering and electronics projects(virtual at home or in-person). Students build everything from a light-up wand to slingshot cars to a night light. This course provides easy-to-follow instructions through an educational context that allows for an enjoyable learning experience. Each project helps kids understand how things work, builds their critical thinking and problem solving skills, and express their imagination in a productive environment.  All project parts come included in the CAKE (Cool Activities for Kids to Engineer) Kit that can be mailed or picked up from our office (if local). 


﻿*Requires access to a computer, internet, and webcam.  

 Instructor to Student Ratio: 1 to 7 ﻿  

 Multiple Classes available from Jan 18 to Mar 26  

 Classes take place 2x a week on a Monday/Wednesday or Tuesday/Thursday schedule  

 Class times: 3 - 4 PM, 4 - 5 PM, 5 - 6 PM (PST)

title: Online STEM Class - Let's Explore STEM
description:
For more information & to register your child, please visit: https://www.dreamsforschools.org/lestem/


Students learn about the world of STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics) in a fun, hands-on interactive class! They build projects like a Magic Light Up Wand or Paper Robot to see what STEM is all about.  This course provides easy-to-follow instructions through an educational context that allows for an enjoyable learning experience. Each day students will explore STEM through mini-activities and experiments. Students will learn about each letter in STEM through 3 to 4 activities.  All activity materials come included in the Dreams for Schools STEAM Kit. Kit can be mailed or pick up at our office (if local).


*Requires access to a computer, internet, and webcam.    

Instructor to Student Ratio: 1 to 7 ﻿    

Multiple Classes available from Jan 18 to Mar 26    

Classes take place 2x a week on a Monday/Wednesday or Tuesday/Thursday schedule    

Class times: 3 - 4 PM, 4 - 5 PM, 5 - 6 PM (PST)

title: CHESS CLUB (Offered at Hayes-Taylor and Spears YMCAs)
description:
The Chess Club allows youth and adults to play and practice their chess skills to improve their strategy and critical thinking, all in a fun and friendly environment.

Hayes-Taylor YMCA:   Tuesdays 6pm-7:30pm; Open to anyone age 5 and up!; Contact Mac Simms for information: 336.272.1101.

Spears YMCA : Request details at the front desk. Chess class is also offered to teach the basic elements of the game.

program:
{'title': 'YMCA of Greensboro', 'description': '

Everyone knows the Y as a place to camp, swim, or exercise, but we\'re so much more. We\'re working side-by-side with our neighbors to address critical community needs that help kids develop into smart, resilient adults, for people to improve their health and build a sense of community, and for our most vulnerable young people to get the care and support they need.

The mission of the YMCA of Greensboro is to put Judeo-Christian principles into practice through programs that build a healthy spirit, mind, and body for all.

The YMCA of Greensboro will be a warm, friendly environment radiating a feeling of belonging and caring where people of all ages, races, faiths, beliefs, and physical and financial abilities participate in worthwhile programs and meaningful experiences that make a positive difference in their lives.

The goal of the YMCA of Greensboro is to turn no one away because of\xa0inability to pay and to provide scholarships on a sliding scale to keep our membership and program fees affordable for those who desire to become a member of the YMCA family.

Be sure to check out our other locations, too! If you would like to become a member, please call us at\xa0 336.478.9622 \ufeff\ufeff\ufeff\ufeff

title: STEM Saturdays - Minecraft Time Travel
description:
In this action filled building adventure, children will use the virtual world of Minecraft as they learn and apply civil, environmental and sustainable engineering practices to their virtual building projects. Students will time travel to ancient civilizations like Egypt, Greece, Rome, traverse through medieval times and industrial age as they learn about stable and strong structures through the ages. They will learn about sustainability in cities and discuss how water, waste, transportation, and energy/electricity worked in our past cities as well as our current cities. Then children will turn the time to the future and apply what they learned from the cities of the past and modern times to design a city of the future! Requirements: You must have a computer/laptop/iPad with Windows 10 and an app called "Minecraft Education Edition" downloaded. We will provide accounts for class.

Click here to learn more﻿

title: Lean Mean Fighting Machine - Biomedicine
description:
In this eye-opening program, children get a closer look at the human body while exploring engineering design and computer programming. Jump into the human body by discovering how health and mechanical engineering come together to explore the skeletal system, joints, and fractures. Once we understand the function of the skeletal system, we'll get up close and personal with the human eye. Children will learn what makes you see, how our brain perceives color, and how virtual reality works. Finally, children will dive into the sense of touch, taste, and smell to explore how these sense organs are impacted by diseases and what role they play in the intake of medicines to cure diseases. Design and code animations and games to teach others about biomedicine. Online Programs   : On your computer or device with web cam and mic.

Click here to learn more﻿

title: City Planning with Minecraft
description:
Calling all Minecraft Gamers! Don't just play vanilla Minecraft! Parents, this is a workshop that takes your child's interest in video gaming to creating something using sustainable practices. In this special online instructor led program, they will learn about sustainability in cities and discuss how water, waste, transportation, and energy/electricity worked in our past cities as well as our current cities. Then children will turn the time to the future and apply what they learned from the cities of the past and modern times to design a city of the future! Requirements: You must have a computer/laptop with Windows 10, iPad, or Chromebook. We will provide accounts for class. ﻿

Click here to learn more﻿

They'll have chickens rain from the sky to a robot that builds a house for them to building skyscrapers and bridges with just computer code they design themselves. Requirements: You must have a computer/laptop with Windows 10, iPad, or Chromebook. We will provide accounts for class.

title: Animated Fun with Artificial Intelligence
description:
There is no better time to get ready for the future than now. Come join us for one of our most cutting edge STEAM programs. In the world where technology has taken over several tasks, get trained to be the one who trains and programs those machines. Learn early on what Artificial Intelligence means. Design games and animations and code your own machines to have them learn various tasks just as humans do. This is a very fun program that blends our very popular game design, animation lab with the machine learning curriculum. Let your creativity go wild and create animations that learn on their own with the help of AI & Machine Learning.

Click here to learn more﻿

program:
{'title': 'Inner Banks STEM Center', 'description': '

Our Mission

1. Expose a diverse mix of youth to Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) topics/careers through aviation, robotics and boating/marine ecology.

2. Improve the relationship between youth and first responders including law enforcement, through a variety of community events

3. Work in partnership with the Beaufort County Health Department and the academic community to educate youth about the importance of fitness, diet and nutrition

4. Develop good life-skills

Curriculum

The IBX STEM curricula are designed by military flight instructors/aviation professionals certified by the Federal Aviation Administration, marine instructors certified by the US Coast Guard Auxiliary and science educators with doctoral-level credentials. Our curricula improve the students\' competence in science through direct instruction, hands-on activities, and field-based inquiry.

The NC state curriculum advocates the teaching of science in ways that are fun, engaging, and exciting. Hands-on activities, experiments, field trips, and project-based learning appeal strongly to youth. Our middle school program follows the protocols contained within the 6 th -8 th \xa0 grade Science, Physical Science and Physics sections as stipulated in the NC Science Essential Standards core objectives. The curriculum is structured to allow for hands-on, inquiry-based exploration of replicable scientific principles, experimentation and technological designs relative to robotics, aviation, and boating.

You can find more information here.\xa0
